channel.title: Welcome on Embedded Systems Design
channel.description: Recent content in Welcome on Embedded Systems Design

item.title: Getting Started with Cadence
item.description: Introduction A number of basic Cadence tutorial videos are available on YouTube.

item.title: Installing Cadence
item.description: Installation System Requirements PC: Windows 10 (64-bit) Professional, Windows Server 2012 and 2012 R2, Windows Server 2016, or greater (Hardware and Software Requirements).

item.title: **Curiosity Nano & MPLAB Tutorial**
item.description: Objectives Getting familiar with the MPLAB X programming environment to program the PIC16F18446 Curiosity Nano development board.

item.title: About Bluetooth Communication (ABC)
item.description: What is Bluetooth Low Energy? Intro to Bluetooth Low Energy video from Cypress Bluetooth Low Energy datasheets from Cypress Developing Bluetooth Smart Applications for Android tutorial from NewCircle Training provides a high-level explanation of how Bluetooth Low Energy works.

item.title: About Version Control
item.description: Part 1 What is Version Control Version control (sometimes called source control) keeps track of changes to files over time.

item.title: Adding Text to a Layout in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: Introduction Text is important on PCB layouts to identify the designers, project, version, components, etc.

item.title: All About Escape Rooms
item.description: What is an escape room? An escape room is a real-life adventure game where you pay to be locked in a room filled with puzzles and given a limited time (usually 60 minutes) to solve the puzzles with your team in order to escape the room.

item.title: All About Serial
item.description: What are serial protocols? I2C, SPI, and UART are three of the most common protocols for serial data transmission.

item.title: All About Smart Homes
item.description: What is a smart home? A smart home links together home comfort, entertainment, appliances, thermostats, lighting, and other electronic devices in a home together such that they can be controlled by voice, gesture, computer, or phone.

item.title: Altering Trace Widths
item.description: Altering Trace Widths Figure 1 Sometimes you need to globally change trace widths in your board after designing it.

item.title: ASU PCB Fabrication Process
item.description: How are PCBs fabricated at ASU? The following video shows our PCB manufacturing process.

item.title: ASU PCB Mill Specs
item.description: Please see this link

item.title: Bypass capacitor basics
item.description: A bypass capacitor (aka “filter cap”) is a small capacitor that dampens electrical noise moving toward an IC.

item.title: Cadence Forward Annotation Tutorial
item.description: Cadence Forward Annotation Tutorial After having started working on a PCB layout, sooner or later you will likely find changes need to be made to your original schematic.

item.title: Cadence Manuals
item.description: Capture CIS Manuals OrCAD Capture Quick Reference OrCAD Capture User’s Guide OrCAD Capture Reference Guide

item.title: Cadence Mounting Hole/Post Tutorial
item.description: Cadence Mounting Hole/Post Tutorial Some components have, in addition to their electrical pins, mechanical supports that must be accounted for in the PCB footprint.

item.title: Cadence schematic tutorials
item.description: There are a number of tutorials available for creating schematics in Cadence.

item.title: Cadence simulation tutorials
item.description: This page lists tutorials for doing circuit simulations in Cadence.

item.title: Cadence Walkthrough: PSoC 4 BLE Module
item.description: Introduction This Cadence walkthrough goes through the process of creating a PSoC® 4 BLE module schematic symbol and PCB footprint.

item.title: Calculating Current Limiting Resistor Value for LEDs
item.description: When calculating the resistance value for your current limiting resistor there are a few variables to consider.

item.title: Changing a Hole Diameter in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: Why would you need to change the hole diameter? The default diameter of holes in Cadence is 0.

item.title: Changing the Default Via Padstack in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: Introduction A via is an electrical interconnection that connects one layer of a PCB to another layer of a PCB.

item.title: Changing the Library Search Path in Cadence Design Entry CIS
item.description: Why would I need to change the library search path? When creating a custom PCB footprint for a component, it is stored somewhere on your computer.

item.title: Changing the Library Search Path in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: Why would I need to change the library search path? When creating a custom PCB footprint for a component, it is stored somewhere on your computer.

item.title: Choosing transistors for high-power digital switching
item.description: Microcontrollers make wonderful “brains” for embedded systems, but are severely limited in the amount of current they can supply to an external device.

item.title: Configuring Cadence
item.description: Before using Cadence, configure it for optimal performance by following the instructions below.

item.title: Configuring the UART on PSoC
item.description: What is a UART (Universal Asynchronous Receiver/Transmitter)? UART is one serial protocol used for communicating data between two digital devices (e.

item.title: Connectors 101
item.description: What is a connector? A connector is an electrical component that links two or more components together.

item.title: Creating a Board Outline in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: What is a board outline? A board outline is the outermost boundary of a printed circuit board design.

item.title: Creating a Custom DC Barrel Jack Schematic Symbol and PCB Footprint in Cadence
item.description: Creating a Custom DC Barrel Jack Schematic Symbol and PCB Footprint in Cadence (Includes Padstack Tutorial)

item.title: Creating a custom library in Cadence
item.description: In order to use schematic symbols imported from the web or custom created for your project (very common), you must create a custom symbol library in which to save them.

item.title: Creating a Custom Padstack (old)
item.description: Introduction A padstack is a design for the exposed copper surface area for each hole or pad on the board where the component is mounted and soldered (see example, Figure 1).

item.title: Creating a custom padstack in Cadence
item.description: Introduction A padstack is a design for the exposed copper surface area for each hole or pad on the board where the component is mounted and soldered (see example, Figure 1).

item.title: Creating a custom PCB footprint manually in Cadence
item.description: Introduction A PCB footprint is the physical layout on a PCB to which a component is soldered.

item.title: Creating a custom PCB footprint using Package Designer in Cadence
item.description: Introduction A PCB footprint is the physical layout on a PCB to which a component is soldered.

item.title: Creating a custom schematic symbol in Cadence
item.description: Introduction In most designs, some components will not be available in built-in libraries.

item.title: Creating a custom SMD footprint manually in Cadence
item.description: Introduction This tutorial will walk through the creation of a custom surface-mount device (SMD) footprint manually.

item.title: Creating a Ground Plane in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: What is a ground plane? A ground plane is a large area of copper in a printed circuit board design that is connected to ground on the power supply.

item.title: Creating a new project in Cadence
item.description: Creating a new project in Cadence In Windows, open the Design Entry CIS program.

item.title: Creating Custom Footprints
item.description: You can try to find existing footprints for components, but most components will require custom footprints.

item.title: DC Motors 101
item.description: Watch the video mini-lecture on DC motor control from Dr. Jordan What types of DC motors are most common?

item.title: Drawing Software
item.description: What is drawing software used for? Drawing software is used to create diagrams for inclusion in presentations and reports.

item.title: Exporting Gerber files from Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: What is a Gerber file? A Gerber file (also known as artwork) is a 2-D graphical representation of a single layer of a PCB.

item.title: Exporting Solder Mask Layers from Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: What is a solder mask? Solder mask is the thin polymer layer that is applied to a printed circuit board to insulate copper traces from unwanted connections.

item.title: Finding existing PCB footprints for Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: Where can I find a list of existing PCB footprints for Cadence PCB Editor?

item.title: From where can I source parts?
item.description: Once you know the types of components that you need for your project, the next step is to find sources/vendors from which you can purchase the components (also known as sourcing parts).

item.title: Fuses 101
item.description: What are fuses and when do I need them? A fuse is an electronic component that protects a circuit by creating an open circuit if it draws too much current.

item.title: Getting Started with Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: What is a printed circuit board (PCB)? See the What is a Printed Circuit Board?

item.title: Grow Your Embedded Programming Skills After EGR 304/314
item.description: Personal Projects and Education a. Arduino Project Hub is where you can learn about what all other beginner or advanced embedded systems designers are building for their own personal needs.

item.title: House of Quality
item.description: What is a House of Quality, and what is it used for?

item.title: How to Create a Silkscreen in Cadence and Manually Add Text to it
item.description: How to Create a Silkscreen in Cadence and Manually Add Text to it Create a (finalized) PCB layout.

item.title: How to export a PDF from Capture and PCB Editor
item.description: Introduction This tutorial goes through how to save CIS schematics and PCB layers as a PDF.

item.title: Integrated Development Environments for PSoC
item.description: In order to program a Cypress Programmable System on a Chip (PSoC®), you first need to install Integrated Development Environment (IDE) software on your computer.

item.title: Interrupts
item.description: What is an interrupt? Consider the following knock-knock joke: Figure 1 Joker: “Knock, knock”

item.title: Interrupts on PSoC
item.description: An interrupt is a signal received by a microcontroller and emitted by hardware or software that is signaling a system event that needs immediate attention.

item.title: Keeping a Schematic Tidy
item.description: Introduction When drawing a schematic, crossing wires can make the schematic difficult to read and follow signals (see example, Figure 1).

item.title: Level shifters
item.description: What is a level shifter? A level shifter either shifts the voltage of a data line up or down depending on what your circuit entails.

item.title: Manual Routing in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: How do I manually route a design in PCB Editor? Your design should have a board outline and components placed, and blue lines (the “rats nest”) between the components (see example, Figure 1).

item.title: Measurement in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: How do I measure the spacing between pins to make sure my footprint matches the Datasheet?

item.title: Mechanical CAD Software
item.description: What is CAD software used for? Computer Aided Drafting (CAD) software is used to capture and simulate designs electronically.

item.title: Merging Multiple Schematics into a Single Schematic
item.description: Merging Multiple Schematics into a Single Schematic Take note of all the files involved in the schematics you are merging, and ensure you have all of them.

item.title: Microchip AVR Microcontrollers
item.description: What microcontrollers does Atmel specialize in? Atmel was one of the top IC manufacturers that makes a number of 8-bit, 32-bit, and ARM microcontrollers, including the AVR microcontroller used in the Arduino.

item.title: Microchip PIC Microcontrollers
item.description: What microcontrollers does Microchip specialize in? Microchip specializes in 8-bit, 16-bit, and 32-bit PIC microcontrollers.

item.title: Motors
item.description: There are many types of motors out there each with their own pros and cons.

item.title: Oscilloscopes 101
item.description: Part I Part II

item.title: Packaging Cadence Files for Submission
item.description: Introduction This tutorial goes through how to package Cadence schematic and PCB files for submission to Canvas.

item.title: Particle Argon Wifi Board
item.description: What is the Particle Argon? What does it do? The Particle Argon is a “wi-fi for everything” development kit that includes a microcontroller, wi-fi hardware, and easy-to-use web-based IDE (Integrated Development Environment).

item.title: Patents 101
item.description: What is a patent? “A patent for an invention is the grant of a property right to the inventor, issued by the United States Patent and Trademark Office” (for more information, see General Information Concerning Patents from the USPTO).

item.title: PCB design checklist
item.description: Before exporting your PCB design for fabrication, you **must **verify the design and fix any errors.

item.title: PCB Text
item.description: Introduction Text is important on PCB layouts to identify the designers, project, version, components, etc.

item.title: Peralta 103 Resources
item.description: What equipment is available at each of the benches? Function Generator (5 MHz)

item.title: Placing and moving components in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: While it is easy to place components using the mouse, most designs require precise placement of some components (e.

item.title: Power Supplies 101
item.description: What are the components of a basic power supply subsystem? Source of power - battery, AC adapter, solar Input electronic noise filtering circuit Voltage regulator to provide a constant supply voltage Output electronic noise filtering circuit What are the design considerations for a battery-operated circuit?

item.title: Printing a PCB Design in DFM Now
item.description: Note: This tutorial shows how to print a PCB design on paper.

item.title: Printing a PCB Layout in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: Note: This tutorial shows how to print a PCB design on paper.

item.title: PSoC 4 Hardware Development Kits
item.description: There are several Cypress Programmable System on a Chip (PSoC®) hardware development kits available for use in designs.

item.title: Pullup/Pulldown resistors
item.description: What are pullup resistors? These are resistors used to pull a volage on a specific pin high.

item.title: Pushing PCB changes back to a schematic in Cadence
item.description: Why would I need to back annotate a design? If you make changes to your design while in PCB Editor (for example, swapping a footprint), you must back annotate (meaning, push changes) from the PCB design back into your original schematic.

item.title: Recreating a simple round padstack
item.description: Recreating a simple round padstack This tutorial takes you through recreating a basic round thru-hole padstack.

item.title: Resetting Reference Designators in Cadence Design Entry CIS
item.description: Introduction When drawing a circuit, you will often move and delete components as part of the process, meaning that the reference designators (e.

item.title: Routing Traces
item.description: See this video

item.title: Running a Design for Manufacturing Check in DFM Now
item.description: Introduction Designs created in an ECAD program may be electrically correct on the screen, but are ultimately constrained by the capabilities of your fabrication equipment.

item.title: Running Design Rules Check in Cadence PCB Editor
item.description: What is a Design Rules Check? Design Rules Check (DRC) is a tool that looks for a limited set of errors in PCB designs, and generates error messages to help you identify and fix the problem(s).

item.title: Schematic checklist
item.description: Before exporting your schematic to create a PCB, you must verify the design and fix errors in the schematic first.

item.title: Software design
item.description: What is a finite state machine? A finite state machine (FSM) is a way of modeling a system such that there are a limited number of finite “states” that a system can be in, and that it can only be in one of those states at a time.

item.title: Soldering and Desoldering Tips and Tricks
item.description: Video Walkthrough How do I turn on the soldering irons in PRLTA 103?

item.title: Sources for Electrical and Electromechanical Components
item.description: Professional Distributors These distributors are often used by professionals in industry, and provide the most complete selection of different parts.

item.title: Sources for Materials
item.description: Adhesives & Tape Adhesives for Paper from ConservationWiki Electronic Grade Self-Leveling Silicone from American Sealants, Inc.

item.title: Sources for Mechanical Components
item.description: General Berg Grainger (* ASU Preferred Supplier) McMaster-Carr Miki Pulley MSC Industrial (* ASU Preferred Supplier) Motor System Parts from Radical RC Stock Drive Products Bearings igus - plastic bushings, bearings, linear guides, and cable carriers.

item.title: SPI & Shift Register Tutorial
item.description: Serial Communication - SPI & Shift Register Tutorial Objectives Getting familiar with the SPI serial communication protocol using MCC under the MPLAB X programming environment to program the PIC16F18446 Curiosity Nano development board and control a shift register to drive 8 LEDs on and off.

item.title: Strategies for using 0 Ohm Resistors
item.description: Why use 0 ohm Resistors in a design? 0 ohm resistors act as a through hole jumper wire on manufactured PCBs.

item.title: Texas Instruments Microcontrollers
item.description: What microcontrollers does Texas Instruments specialize in? Texas Instruments (TI) specializes in low-power, performance, and wireless microcontrollers.

item.title: The First Three Questions You Should Ask When Debugging Your PCB and Possible Solutions
item.description: Are Connections Continuous? Conduct a continuity check on your board with a multimeter.

item.title: Trace Width Calculator
item.description: Check this link

item.title: Transferring a Cadence schematic to PCB Editor
item.description: Introduction In order to create a PCB, you must first prepare the schematic and check for errors, export a netlist of the schematic, import the netlist into PCB editor, and design the PCB.

item.title: Transistors
item.description: What is a transistor? A transistor is a type of semiconductor device that can be used as both an amplifier or as an electronic switch.

item.title: Types of Logic Operators and How to Use Them
item.description: What are Logical Operators? Say you are out grabbing lunch on behalf of a friend or a fellow student, and their lunch comes with a maximum of two sides for free.

item.title: UART PIC to Argon Tutorial
item.description: UART PIC to Argon Tutorial Objectives Getting familiar with UART on both PIC and Particle platforms.

item.title: Updating a Part in your Library
item.description: Updating a Part in your Library Figure: Typical Schematic Sometimes its necessary to make small changes to your parts as you learn more about them or need to define them better in order to identify more design mistakes during the design process.

item.title: Using Bitwise Operators in C
item.description: What are bitwise operators? Bitwise operators allow access to individual bits in a variable or register.

item.title: Using GitHub to Manage Project Files
item.description: GitHub is a programing organization tool that not only can store all your programs nicely but allow you to collaborate with others on the same “repository” (or 304/314 project folder in layman’s terms).

item.title: Using VCC and GND Symbols
item.description: You can use VCC (power) and GND (ground) symbols to connect power and ground instead of manually routing wires across your schematic.

item.title: What is a Gantt Chart?
item.description: A Gantt Chart is a common project management tool that helps teams understand the phases of a project, deadlines, critical paths, and interdependencies between tasks.

item.title: What is a printed circuit board?
item.description: A printed circuit board (PCB) is a board made of both conducive and non-conductive materials onto which components can be soldered to create a circuit.

item.title: What is Cadence?
item.description: Cadence is an electronic computer-aided drafting (ECAD) program commonly used in industry for the design and simulation of electronic circuits and printed circuit boards.

item.title: What is PSoC?
item.description: The Cypress Programmable System on a Chip (PSoC®) is a mixed-signal electronic hardware platform that integrates a microcontroller core, programmable analog signal processing blocks, programmable digital hardware blocks, and capacitive touch sensing.

item.title: Working with Libraries
item.description: Working with Libraries - THIS IS A DUPLICATE TUTORIAL This tutorial details how to add and save a custom library.
